abstract: An Australian high court allowed the release of dozens of detained people who are now subject to curfews and monitored by the government with ankle bracelets.
lead_paragraph: When Gus Kuster finished a one-year prison sentence in Australia, he anticipated rebuilding his life there, in the only country he has ever known. Instead, as a noncitizen and stateless person, he spent the following five years being shuttled between grim immigration detention centers, with seemingly no release date in sight.
headline: Freed From Never-Ending Detention, They Ended Up in Another Limbo
keywords: Australia;Immigration Detention;Ex-Convicts;Asylum, Right of;Refugees and Displaced Persons;Politics and Government;Curfews;Surveillance of Citizens by Government

abstract: An idealistic teacher in a German school meets reality, and it’s messier than she could have imagined.
lead_paragraph: Teaching, like parenting or skiing or governing or making a souffle, is an activity you can learn about from books and classes and movies, but only really understand on the job. Carla Nowak (Leonie Benesch), a new teacher in a German school, seems to have arrived in her sixth-grade classroom armed with theories and techniques for gaining the trust and respect of her students. But she’s about to discover, as many a teacher has before, that actually managing a classroom is not as easy as they make it seem on TV.
headline: ‘The Teachers’ Lounge’ Review: A Whole Civilization in the Classroom
keywords: Movies;The Teachers' Lounge (Movie);Catak, Ilker

abstract: George Clooney’s film covers a high water point when the University of Washington’s junior varsity crew paddled all the way to the 1936 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: “The Boys in the Boat,” directed by George Clooney, is an old-fashioned movie about old-fashioned moxie. Based on a section of Daniel James Brown’s 2013 nonfiction book of the same name, and set to a plucky score by Alexandre Desplat, it’s a handsome, forthright flashback to a high water point of the Depression Era when the University of Washington’s junior varsity crew paddled all the way to the 1936 Olympics. Approximately 300 million radio listeners tuned in to hear live sporting news from Berlin, and the film cuts to what feels like all of them rooting on these tall, ruddy and heroic amateurs. I’ve never seen a movie with this much applause — the extras must have been as winded as the athletes.
headline: ‘The Boys in the Boat’ Review: Taking Up Oars
keywords: Movies;Clooney, George;Turner, Callum;Brown, Daniel James;The Boys in the Boat (Movie)

abstract: The artist and former gallerist Aaron Rose had the coolest indie gallery in an era of creative explosion in downtown New York. A new book (of old work) captures that long-lost moment.

headline: Drunken, Youthful Poems Unearthed From the ’90s

abstract: In his four-and-half-hour documentary, the British director Steve McQueen charts the fate of Amsterdam’s Jewish population during the Nazi occupation.
lead_paragraph: Early in Steve McQueen’s extraordinary documentary “Occupied City,” the film cuts to the interior of the elegant main hall in Amsterdam’s grand Royal Concertgebouw. In World War II, the Nazi-German occupiers held events in the hall, but at some point in 1942 the names of the Jewish composers adorning it were covered. Concerts continued, but without Jewish composers, conductors, orchestra musicians, concertgoers and even names on walls.
headline: ‘Occupied City’ Review: Mapping the Holocaust, Street by Street
keywords: Occupied City (Movie);McQueen, Steve (Filmmaker);Documentary Films and Programs;Stigter, Bianca;AMSTERDAM (NETHERLANDS);Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Jews and Judaism

abstract: Backstage with the breakout supergroup of the year.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in the movie “Help!” where the Beatles roll up to a row of terraced houses and approach their adjacent front doors — four separate entrances, one for each Beatle. Then the camera cuts inside, and we see that all four doors lead into one immense mid-1960s playhouse, where the Beatles live together. This was and is the fantasy of a rock band: boys, together, reveling in a world of their own making. Beastie Boys. Beach Boys. Backstreet Boys. They are cute. They are straight. They are inseparable and nearly indistinguishable, like sitcom characters. They seem to travel with their own center of gravity. All for one and one for all.
headline: boygenius Is Having All the Fun
keywords: internal-sub-only;internal-great-read;boygenius (Music Group);Pop and Rock Music;Content Type: Personal Profile;Dacus, Lucy (1995- );Baker, Julien (1995- );Bridgers, Phoebe (1994- )

abstract: The yearning for the comfort of processed foods from my youth.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food. As a child, he relished a good Big Mac, a box of chicken nuggets and a cold, refreshing Sprite. But after moving to the East Coast for college, Rivera’s socioeconomic circles began shifting, as well as his worldview around food. In this audio essay, he reflects on his relationship with processed food, class and what it’s like to go home with a new set of tastes.
headline: Proust Had Madeleines. I Have McNuggets.
keywords: audio-neutral-informative;Food;Fast Food Industry;Diet and Nutrition

abstract: The director’s portrait of the Italian racecar impresario roars to life on the road, but home is a torment. Adam Driver stars with Penélope Cruz and Shailene Woodley.
lead_paragraph: In “Ferrari,” Adam Driver looms like a colossus as Enzo Ferrari. Driver is tall and rangy, but he looks even bigger here — wider, too — partly because Enzo wears boxy suits with linebacker shoulders so broad they nearly scrape the edges of the frame. The most famous man in Italy aside from the Pope, Enzo makes blood-red racecars with sexy curves and supercharged engines. The Commendatore, as he’s called, looks more like a tank. He seems an ideal vehicle for Michael Mann, a filmmaker with his own line of beautiful obsessions.
headline: ‘Ferrari’ Review: Michael Mann Puts You in the Driver’s Seat
keywords: Movies;Ferrari (Movie);Ferrari SpA;Mann, Michael;Cruz, Penelope;Woodley, Shailene;Ferrari, Enzo;Driver, Adam

abstract: Great holiday reads and a look back at the year.
lead_paragraph: At a dairy farm in New York this month, carolers serenaded a herd of 28 cattle. Across Europe, Christmas markets popped up like fairy-dusted street fairs. And there’s cheer to be found even in the farthest reaches of the cosmos — the winking lights of the Christmas Tree Galaxy Cluster shine from approximately 4.3 billion light-years away.
headline: A Special Christmas Briefing
keywords: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas;Christmas

abstract: The Harvard Corporation is a powerful board that governs the university. Here’s what we know about the members.
lead_paragraph: Amid the turmoil over Harvard University’s president, Claudine Gay, the powerful board governing the university has been thrust into the spotlight. Despite the mounting scrutiny over Dr. Gay, the Harvard Corporation has so far shown support for her.
headline: Who Are the Members of the Harvard Corporation?
keywords: Harvard University;Gay, Claudine;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Plagiarism;Anti-Semitism
